Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Effects of External Threats on Community Cohesion

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project examines effects of a difficult environment on individuals and their community. In a situation in which hardships have increased recently, this study looks at the effects on 1) mental health challenges for individuals and their groups; 2) how the community understands itself and its place within the larger social structure of the United States; and (3) commitments of individuals and groups within the community to support each other, including opportunities for social solidarity and collective action in defense of vulnerable members. Findings will contribute to the understanding of the indirect effects of policies and their enforcement, and thus will be useful to policymakers as well as to organizations seeking to influence policy and to the affected communities themselves.

Qualitative data will be collected on the practices and relationships of members of the community and on the extent to which legal and enforcement threats shape their social, economic and psychological well-being. The main methodological procedure is the construction of case studies of groups of community members through long-term ethnographic observation and interviews, often repeated, with key informants and community members. Results will contribute to the theoretical understanding of how social solidarity in communities is generated; how external processes condition the well-being of individuals and groups; and how the effects of these external processes may be modified through community characteristics and processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In an era in which structures of mass incarceration and technologies of surveillance are rapidly growing, we urgently need more information about the ways that families and communities are collectively managing the threat these systems pose to their well-being. My project responds to this need, by exploring both in-depth and over time the way that individuals and collectives work to adapt to the external threats, and the way these processes of adaptation re-shape their understandings of their place in the U.S., as well as their community. I explore these processes by drawing from a substantial body of data, collected over the course of two years with the support of the National Science Foundation. Over the course of these two years I produced a detailed archive of field notes which consists of more than 1600 pages of typed text (over 580,000 words), as well as conducted 85 in-depth interviews. This study has several important implications for advancing the sociological understanding of cultural narratives, criminalization and social movements.

My most important contributions to the literature are the insights my dissertation provides regarding the social life of cultural narratives. My data shows how people use cultural narratives to help them cope with the challenges they face, as well as to anticipate their social vulnerabilities by comparing themselves with others in their community. I observed how cultural narratives played a role in the ways that individuals comforted themselves about their own vulnerabilities to social exclusion, as well as the ways they utilized dominant narratives to understand- and sometimes- justify the social exclusion of others. These coping processes ultimately lead to the reproduction of hierarchies of power and privilege within a marginalized community, as they way marginalized community members understood individual’s responsibility for their social exclusion shaped their own willingness to offer support. My analysis reveals that while the use of particular cultural narratives can help alleviate some of the anxieties that accompany social vulnerability, they can also create social hierarchies that fragment the development of collective solidarity.  My evidence also shows how changing political circumstances can motivate the transformation and adaptation of cultural narratives, with implications for the growth and dissemination of social movements.

This project also shows the importance of examining the overlaps between experiences of illegality and criminality- pointing the ways that these distinctions matter, and the circumstances that cause these distinctions to collapse, within the day to day experiences of mixed-status immigrant families. While the literature would predict that an increase in police surveillance and the removal of social protections would be accompanied by social withdrawal and division, my work speaks to the generative aspects of dramatic political changes that can motivate shifts in criminalizing narratives and an increased sensitivity to issues of social justice. I add to the immigration literature by investigating how local context shapes social understandings of illegality, and by more deeply exploring the spillover effects that the threat of deportation has on the communities in which undocumented migrants are embedded. My findings speak to how public policy shapes how people – immigrant or not, documented or not, Latinx or not - come to understand their belonging within their larger sociopolitical context and their neighborhoods, and develop flexible strategies of adaptation that foment resilience in the face of uncertainty and hardship.

My project also had broader impacts within the community of my research. I produced project reports for several community-based organizations that spoke to the mental health consequences of political changes among organization’s members, provided insights as to the way individual members were perceiving organizational actions and priorities, and supplied evidence of organizational impacts that were useful in organizational applications for grants and external funding. I was invited to speak about my findings at several employee and volunteer training events for advocacy organizations, and I gave over 15 presentations about mental health within public schools in the city of Chicago. Empirical results demonstrating the effects of political changes on different groups within the community may also be useful in the future for organizations seeking to direct policy change.
